thread.title: Big resources firms scramble to cover contractor collapse
thread.title_full: Big resources firms scramble to cover contractor collapse

author: Peter Ker
title: Big resources firms scramble to cover contractor collapse
text:
Rumours of WDS' demise had been circulating in the coal sector as early as last week.
Some of Australia's biggest mining and energy companies were scrambling to make arrangements this week after their contractor WDS Ltd went into receivership.
WDS Ltd finally went into administration after an ignition incident at a Queensland coal mine owned by Brazilian miner Vale led to the contractor's debts piling up.
WDS had been a contractor to a range of coal miners in recent years, including Glencore, Yancoal and South32, and had also worked extensively in natural gas for Shell and PetroChina, Origin at the Australia Pacific LNG plant and on Santos' GLNG project.
Rumours of WDS' collapse had been circulating in the coal sector as early as last week, but it wasn't until Wednesday that WDS announced it had gone into administration.
Advertisement WDS was expected to post a full-year loss of about $14 million but struck trouble when it was involved in the ignition incident at Vale's Eagle Downs coal mine in Queensland.
Vale's decision to cash in an insurance bond for $14.2 million left WDS with even bigger liabilities, which breached a covenant on the debt it owed to GE.
Korda Mentha was appointed as administrator of WDS on Tuesday, and GE appointed FTI Consulting to act as a receiver later in the week.
WDS management refused to tell Fairfax Media earlier this week if all subcontractors and workers had been paid their wages, but it is understood that issue has been taken care of since the company went into receivership.
WDS had been contracting for South32 at the Appin mine near Wollongong, and the miner said it was seeking to make contingency plans in the wake of this week's events.
"Illawarra Coal is making contingency arrangements to manage any potential impacts and is waiting for further advice on the matter," a South32 spokesman said.
A Glencore spokesman said the company did not expect any delays or impacts.
Santos, Shell and PetroChina's Arrow Energy joint venture did not respond to requests for comment.
WDS' problems continue a dark period for mining and energy contractors in Australia, which were the canaries in the coal mine for the fading resources boom.
Most contractors have had their market valuations slashed over recent years, while some, like Western Australian company Forge, have collapsed.
